Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Improved Spare Parts Inventory Management in Aircraft Engines through Hybrid Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award is to develop the basic science and necessary tools to transform sensor measurements from a large set of machine equipment in the field into reliable forecasts and inventory policies for the spare parts required to maintain that equipment. While equipment health monitoring is of relevance to many manufacturers, the application context of this research is commercial jet engines. The research consists of four key steps: advancing sensing methods and the interpretation of signals to diagnose engine condition; developing procedures for transforming this data into predictions of time-to-overhaul and resource-requirements; building part forecasting methods and inventory policies that aggregate this information across engines in the field, with consideration of usage and economic conditions; and creating a simulation tool for the monitoring and maintenance of a large fleet to validate the methodology.

This research will establish a framework for modeling and simulating the process of engine maintenance, and will produce theoretical results that can be translated into applicable tools of practical value to the industrial partner and the aerospace industry at large, leading to improved forecasting and inventory management for spare parts. While currently-used sensor data can provide an indication of the overall health of the engine, the advanced sensing technologies developed in this research offer the potential to predict which specific parts will need replacement before an overhaul is initiated, thus providing more time to secure the necessary resources. This research will determine the economic impact of the additional health information and improved decision-making enabled by these advanced sensing technologies, and will potentially make the case for their pervasive installation. Although the models will primarily be validated within the industrial partner's business units, they will be beneficial to a wide array of manufacturing firms for whom after-sales service is a critical component of their business.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

This research developed a framework for incorporating sensor data into the forecasting and inventory control decisions for the spare parts that are used to maintain a complex device. This framework extends standard forecasting and inventory models to incorporate complexities such as the periodic updating of the maintenance decision-making based on observed sensor data, evolving economic conditions, and updated usage plans. The forecasting and inventory models also incorporate the decision regarding when to perform maintenance given the planned maintenance schedule and the real-time sensor observations obtained from the device. This model allows for the joint optimization of the spare parts inventory and maintenance decisions. The model and solution approach were developed based on input from an industrial partner.

We also extend this inventory model to consider the impact of maintenance flexibility on the spare parts inventory requirements. The model incorporates two types of demand for spare parts: demand generated by scheduled preventative maintenance and by unscheduled maintenance, which results from unusual behavior (e.g., sudden changes) in the observed real-time sensor data. While scheduled maintenance can be delayed without causing a significant disruption, unscheduled maintenance is more critical, requiring an immediate response. This model is used to demonstrate the value of flexibility in performing scheduled maintenance, where the inventory held to meet the scheduled maintenance can be used to perform unscheduled maintenance, if necessary.

Finally, this project also analyzed the failure rate characteristics of remaining life distributions when those distribution are updated using real-time sensor data. The results demonstrate that this updating can fundamentally change the failure rate characteristics, i.e., whether the failure rate is increasing, decreasing or constant. This observation is critical given that the optimal maintenance policy is dependent on the failure rate characteristics and that most commonly used maintenance policies assume an increasing failure rate.

 Broader impacts:

The broader impacts of this research were four-fold. First, this project enhanced a long-term collaborative relationship between the industrial and academic partners. Second, this research developed a general modeling framework and theoretical results, which can be translated into applicable tools of practical value and lead to improved parts forecasting and inventory management. While the models and results were developed within the industrial partner’s business units, they will also be beneficial to a wide array of firms that provide after-sales services. Third, the simulation methods developed in this research are used to quantify the benefits associated with using condition monitoring data in making operational decisions, and thus improve our understanding of the value of the required condition monitoring technology. Fourth, the research contributed to undergraduate and graduate education and training. The models and results developed in this research, as well as the broader understanding of engine diagnostics and maintenance acquired through interactions with the industrial partner, are incorporated into the courses taught by the researchers. In addition, the graduate students associated with the project benefited extensively from their interactions with the industrial partner.
